children.value: are abstract GraphQL types that enable a schema field to return one of multiple object types.
When you define a union type, you declare which object types are included in the union:
union Media = Book | Movie
A field can have a union (or a list of that union) as its return type. In this case, it can return any object type that's included in the union:

type Query {
  allMedia: [Media] # This list can include both Book and Movie objects
}
All of a union's included types must be
(not scalars, input types, etc.). Included types do
union type that can return either a

union SearchResult = Book | Author
type Book {
  title: String!
}

type Author {
  name: String!
}

type Query {
  search(contains: String): [SearchResult!]}
to return a list that includes both
GraphQL clients don't know which object type a field will return if the field's return type is a union. To account for this, a query can include the subfields of
Here's a valid query for the schema above:

query GetSearchResults {
  search(contains: "Shakespeare") {
    # Querying for __typename is almost always recommended,
    # but it's even more important when querying a field that
    # might return one of multiple types.
    __typename
    ... on Book {
      title
    }
    ... on Author {
      name
    }
  }
}
Here's a valid result for the above query:

{
  "data": {
    "search": [
      {
        "__typename": "Book",
        "title": "The Complete Works of William Shakespeare"
      },
      {
        "__typename": "Author",
        "name": "William Shakespeare"
      }
    ]
  }
}
Using fragments with unions and interfaces
To fully resolve a union, Apollo Server needs to specify
of the union's types is being returned. To achieve this, you define a
function for the union in your resolver map.
function is responsible for determining an object's corresponding GraphQL type and returning the name of that type as a string. It can use any logic to do so, such as:
Checking for the presence or absence of fields that are unique to a particular type in the union
object's type is related to its

const resolvers = {
  SearchResult: {
    __resolveType(obj, context, info){      // Only Author has a name field      if(obj.name){        return 'Author';      }      // Only Book has a title field      if(obj.title){        return 'Book';      }      return null; // GraphQLError is thrown    },  },
  Query: {
    search: () => { ... }
  },
};

const server = new ApolloServer({
  typeDefs,
  resolvers,
});

server.listen().then(({ url }) => {
  console.log(`🚀 Server ready at ${url}`)
});
the name of a valid type, the associated operation produces a GraphQL error.
An interface specifies a set of fields that multiple object types can include:

interface Book {
  title: String!
  author: Author!
}

type Textbook implements Book {
  title: String! # Must be present
  author: Author! # Must be present
  courses: [Course!]!
}
A field can have an interface (or a list of that interface) as its return type. In this case, it can return any object type that

type Query {
  books: [Book!] # Can include Textbook objects
}
interface, along with two object types that implement it:

interface Book {
  title: String!
  author: Author!
}

type Textbook implements Book {
  title: String!
  author: Author!
  courses: [Course!]!
}

type ColoringBook implements Book {
  title: String!
  author: Author!
  colors: [String!]!
}

type Query {
  books: [Book!]!
}
returns a list that can include both
If a field's return type is an interface, clients can query that field for any subfields included in the interface:

query GetBooks {
  books {
    title
    author
  }
}

query GetBooks {
  books {
    # Querying for __typename is almost always recommended,
    # but it's even more important when querying a field that
    # might return one of multiple types.
    __typename
    title
    ... on Textbook {
      courses { # Only present in Textbook
        name
      }
    }
    ... on ColoringBook {
      colors # Only present in ColoringBook
    }
  }
}
Here's a valid result for the above query:

{
  "data": {
    "books": [
      {
        "__typename": "Textbook",
        "title": "Wheelock's Latin",
        "courses": [
          {
            "name": "Latin I"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "__typename": "ColoringBook",
        "title": "Oops All Water",
        "colors": [
          "Blue"
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
Using fragments with unions and interfaces
, Apollo Server requires interfaces to define a
function to determine which implementing object type is being returned.

const resolvers = {
  Book: {
    __resolveType(book, context, info){      // Only Textbook has a courses field      if(book.courses){        return 'Textbook';      }      // Only ColoringBook has a colors field      if(book.colors){        return 'ColoringBook';      }      return null; // GraphQLError is thrown    },  },
  Query: {
    books: () => { ... }
  },
};
